articles.headline: U.S. Training in Africa Aims to Deter Extremists
articles.snippet: Americans are training African armies to guard their borders against infiltration by Al Qaeda’s militants.
articles.abstract: Americans are training African armies to guard their borders against infiltration by Al Qaeda’s militants.
articles.lead_paragraph: KATI, Mali  Thousands of miles from the battlefields of Iraq and Afghanistan, another side of America’s fight against terrorism is unfolding in this remote corner of West Africa. American Green Berets are training African armies to guard their borders and patrol vast desolate expanses against infiltration by Al Qaeda’s militants, so the United States does not have to.

articles.headline: Be Smart, but Don’t Think That You’re Special
articles.snippet: Strategies to avoid being an investor caught with one’s life savings in the mess surrounding Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.abstract: Strategies to avoid being an investor caught with one’s life savings in the mess surrounding Bernard L. Madoff.
articles.lead_paragraph: When wealthy investors are willing to hand over a sizable sum to a single money manager they heard about at the country club, certain first principles of investing bear repeating.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Starting Over, With a Second Career Goal of Changing Society
articles.snippet: Harvard's small but ambitious experiment for student-fellows in their 50s and 60s hopes to become a new “third stage” of university education.
articles.abstract: Harvard's small but ambitious experiment for student-fellows in their 50s and 60s hopes to become a new “third stage” of university education.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harvard kicked off a small but ambitious experiment this week that it hopes will become a new “third stage” of university education. For the student-fellows in the program, most in their 50s and early 60s, the goal is a second-act career in a new stage of life.

articles.headline: Store Brands Lift Grocers in Troubled Times
articles.snippet: Grocery stores are finding private-label brands, whether generic or premium quality, increasingly profitable.
articles.abstract: Grocery stores are finding private-label brands, whether generic or premium quality, increasingly profitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOVELAND, Ohio  Linda Severin, a Kroger vice president, has spent the last two years dreaming up new products to sell under the chain’s store-brand labels. Her creations, while inexpensive compared to national brands, are often fancier than the store brands of old. They include Mediterranean-style pizzas and cake mix with edible images of princesses.

articles.headline: U.A.W. Chief and Senator Gain From Face-Off
articles.snippet: Ron Gettelfinger and Senator Robert Phillips Corker Jr. have emerged strengthened from the auto bailout talks.
articles.abstract: Ron Gettelfinger and Senator Robert Phillips Corker Jr. have emerged strengthened from the auto bailout talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  For more than 70 years, the United Automobile Workers union has known who its adversaries were: company executives, foreign automakers and right-to-work advocates who fought its organizing drives.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Look at Wall St. Wizard Finds Magic Had Skeptics
articles.snippet: Questions are swirling about whether Bernard L. Madoff acted alone and why his suspected con game, in which billions were lost, was not uncovered sooner.
articles.abstract: Questions are swirling about whether Bernard L. Madoff acted alone and why his suspected con game, in which billions were lost, was not uncovered sooner.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, investors, rivals and regulators all wondered how Bernard L. Madoff worked his magic.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Diana B. Henriques

articles.headline: Sorry, Obamas, Early Check-In Isn’t Available
articles.snippet: The Obamas had asked to move into Blair House early, so their daughters can start school Jan. 5., but were denied.
articles.abstract: The Obamas had asked to move into Blair House early, so their daughters can start school Jan. 5., but were denied.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  To the list of people having trouble finding somewhere in Washington to stay in early January, there can now be added one more entry: the Obama family.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Rachel L. Swarns

articles.headline: For Investors, Trust Lost, and Money Too
articles.snippet: Many of Bernard L. Madoff’s clients are facing an abrupt reversal of fortune that is the stuff of nightmares.
articles.abstract: Many of Bernard L. Madoff’s clients are facing an abrupt reversal of fortune that is the stuff of nightmares.
articles.lead_paragraph: The zoning lawyer in Miami trusted him because his father had dealt profitably with him for decades. The officers of a little charity in Massachusetts respected him and relied on his advice.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Alex Berenson

articles.headline: Wyeth’s Use of Medical Ghostwriters Questioned
articles.snippet: The pharmaceutical company paid ghostwriters to produce articles favorable to its drug Prempro, according to Congressional letters.
articles.abstract: The pharmaceutical company paid ghostwriters to produce articles favorable to its drug Prempro, according to Congressional letters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wyeth, the pharmaceutical company, paid ghostwriters to produce medical journal articles favorable to its hormone replacement therapy Prempro, according to Congressional letters seeking more information about the company’s involvement in medical ghostwriting. At least one article was published even after a federal study found the drug raised the risk of breast cancer.

articles.headline: Obama’s Friends Form Strategy to Stay Close
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s closest friends have promised to stay tight-knit once the first family enters the White House.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s closest friends have promised to stay tight-knit once the first family enters the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Sunday night, President-elect Barack Obama’s three closest friends — Valerie Jarrett, Martin Nesbitt and Dr. Eric Whitaker — sat down in the study of Mr. Nesbitt’s house in Chicago for one of their increasingly frequent heart-to-hearts.

articles.headline: A Champion of Wall Street Reaps Benefits
articles.snippet: In Washington, Senator Charles E. Schumer is beneficiary, advocate and overseer of an industry that is his hometown’s most important business.
articles.abstract: In Washington, Senator Charles E. Schumer is beneficiary, advocate and overseer of an industry that is his hometown’s most important business.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We are not going to rest until we change the rules, change the laws and make sure New York remains No. 1 for decades on into the future.” Senator Charles E. Schumer, referring to financial regulations, Jan. 22, 2007
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Raymond Hernandez

articles.headline: The Man Who Is Unwinding Lehman Brothers
articles.snippet: Harvey R. Miller has been consumed by the largest corporate liquidation in U.S. history.
articles.abstract: Harvey R. Miller has been consumed by the largest corporate liquidation in U.S. history.
articles.lead_paragraph: THESE days, it’s awfully hard to get on Harvey R. Miller’s calendar.

articles.headline: Blank Check for Banks, Pink Slips for Detroit
articles.snippet: If Capitol Hill can scrutinize Detroit automakers, it should question financial institutions as well.
articles.abstract: If Capitol Hill can scrutinize Detroit automakers, it should question financial institutions as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE in Bailout Nation, you’ll be surprised to learn, some of us are more equal than others.

articles.headline: Nascar’s Sponsors, Hit by Sticker Shock
articles.snippet: Nascar, which relies on corporate sponsorships more than other sports, is particularly vulnerable in an economic crisis.
articles.abstract: Nascar, which relies on corporate sponsorships more than other sports, is particularly vulnerable in an economic crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT the Indianapolis Motor Speedway last July, the parking lot was filled with excited Nascar fans chugging beer, roasting pigs and exchanging drivers’ statistics.

articles.headline: Official History Spotlights Iraq Rebuilding Blunders
articles.snippet: A federal history of the U.S.-led reconstruction of Iraq depicts the effort as crippled by poor planning, waste and deception.
articles.abstract: A federal history of the U.S.-led reconstruction of Iraq depicts the effort as crippled by poor planning, waste and deception.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  An unpublished 513-page federal history of the American-led reconstruction of Iraq depicts an effort crippled before the invasion by Pentagon planners who were hostile to the idea of rebuilding a foreign country, and then molded into a $100 billion failure by bureaucratic turf wars, spiraling violence and ignorance of the basic elements of Iraqi society and infrastructure.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and T. Christian Miller

articles.headline: After Its Big Cuts, Detroit Makes Lots of Small Ones
articles.snippet: As sales continue to plummet, the Big Three automakers are scrutinizing every budget line for potential savings to save cash.
articles.abstract: As sales continue to plummet, the Big Three automakers are scrutinizing every budget line for potential savings to save cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The threat of bankruptcy is evident every night at General Motors headquarters, when the lights are turned out early and the escalators and nearly all the elevators are shut down to save money.

articles.headline: Fannie Mae Lets Renters Stay Despite Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The loan giant said it would sign new leases with renters in foreclosed properties, aiding those who face eviction.
articles.abstract: The loan giant said it would sign new leases with renters in foreclosed properties, aiding those who face eviction.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that provides relief to thousands of renters who face eviction but draws the federal government even deeper into the housing market, the loan giant Fannie Mae said Sunday that it would sign new leases with renters living in foreclosed properties owned by the company.

articles.headline: A Scandal in Chicago That Justifies Investigative Journalism
articles.snippet: Newspapers, smacked around for lacking relevance the last few years, have found a compelling spokesman: Rod R. Blagojevich, the governor of Illinois.
articles.abstract: Newspapers, smacked around for lacking relevance the last few years, have found a compelling spokesman: Rod R. Blagojevich, the governor of Illinois.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last few years, newspapers have been smacked around for lacking relevance, but the industry has finally found a compelling spokesman: Rod R. Blagojevich, Democratic governor of Illinois.

articles.headline: Fleeing Investors Put a Strain on Funds
articles.snippet: Many investors are fleeing hedge funds and using the cash to cover losses on their other investments, leaving money managers struggling to cope with the rush.
articles.abstract: Many investors are fleeing hedge funds and using the cash to cover losses on their other investments, leaving money managers struggling to cope with the rush.
articles.lead_paragraph: The game ended for Bernard L. Madoff when some of his investors finally asked for their money back. He did not have it, and his suspected Ponzi scheme collapsed.

articles.headline: A Palm Beach Enclave, Stunned by an Inside Job
articles.snippet: At the exclusive Palm Beach Country Club, trust extended to a fellow member turns to angst after the collapse of Bernard L. Madoff’s suspected $50 billion Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: At the exclusive Palm Beach Country Club, trust extended to a fellow member turns to angst after the collapse of Bernard L. Madoff’s suspected $50 billion Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla.  The room of somber whispers fell silent when the two men walked in.

articles.headline: MediaNews Sees Bad Timing on Newspapers, Not Bad Bets
articles.snippet: Dean Singleton gambled his company on California -- where the crash in housing has hit newspapers especially hard -- just as the bottom was about to fall out for newspapers.
articles.abstract: Dean Singleton gambled his company on California -- where the crash in housing has hit newspapers especially hard -- just as the bottom was about to fall out for newspapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE  Dean Singleton expanded his newspaper empire at the worst possible time, in the worst part of the country he could have chosen, and he has been paying the price ever since in plummeting advertising and shrinking papers. Yet somehow, even in today’s adverse climate, he professes optimism.

articles.headline: Battle in a Poor Land for Riches Beneath the Soil
articles.snippet: A fight over uranium, an unrealized bonanza in one of the world’s poorest nations, could mean more misery in Niger.
articles.abstract: A fight over uranium, an unrealized bonanza in one of the world’s poorest nations, could mean more misery in Niger.
articles.lead_paragraph: AIR MOUNTAINS, Niger  Until last year, the only trigger Amoumoun Halil had pulled was the one on his livestock-vaccination gun. This spring, a battered Kalashnikov rifle rested uneasily on his shoulder. When he donned his stiff fatigues, his lopsided gait and smiling eyes stood out among his hard-faced guerrilla brethren.

articles.headline: The Disability Board That Couldn’t Say No
articles.snippet: Operating with little scrutiny, the Railroad Retirement Board approves nearly every disability application.
articles.abstract: Operating with little scrutiny, the Railroad Retirement Board approves nearly every disability application.
articles.lead_paragraph: After learning that most of her career employees were retiring early and getting disability payments, the Long Island Rail Road’s president, Helena E. Williams, set out in October to learn more about the obscure federal agency in Chicago that was dispensing the money, a quarter of a billion dollars since 2000.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Nicholas Phillips

articles.headline: Two Sides of a Troubled Governor, Sinking Deeper
articles.snippet: Many who know Rod R. Blagojevich well say the Illinois governor has seemed panicked or delusional recently.
articles.abstract: Many who know Rod R. Blagojevich well say the Illinois governor has seemed panicked or delusional recently.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich is a polished speaker who can win over elderly women at luncheons in southern Illinois with his earnest attention and eloquently recite historical anecdotes from the lives of the leaders he says he most admires  Theodore Roosevelt, Abraham Lincoln, Robert F. Kennedy, Alexander Hamilton, Ronald Reagan.

articles.headline: The 17th Floor, Where Wealth Went to Vanish
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff’s offices in Midtown Manhattan are now an occupied zone, as investigators piece together an alleged Ponzi scheme worth billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff’s offices in Midtown Manhattan are now an occupied zone, as investigators piece together an alleged Ponzi scheme worth billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: The epicenter of what may be the largest Ponzi scheme in history was the 17th floor of the Lipstick Building, an oval red-granite building rising 34 floors above Third Avenue in Midtown Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Alex Berenson
